Incident Atrial Fibrillation (AF) after SHHS Visit 1
description: Variable created as part of the analysis for [Tung et al. 2017 (PubMed ID: 28668820)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28668820). Incident AF was considered present if AF was identified on a 12-lead ECG obtained at the second SHHS exam or was adjudicated by the parent cohorts at any time between the baseline PSG and the final follow-up date for AF ascertainment of June 30, 2006.

display_name: Prevalent Atrial Fibrillation (AF) at SHHS Visit 1
description: Variable created as part of the analysis for [Tung et al. 2017 (PubMed ID: 28668820)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28668820). Prevalent AF was defined by any of the following: a positive response to the question 'Has a doctor ever told you that you have or had atrial fibrillation'; AF identified on resting 12-lead ECG at the baseline SHHS exam; or if the parent study identified AF documented in the medical record before the SHHS baseline exam.

display_name: Health Interview (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit One (SHHS1)): How stressful was day today
description: How stressful was your day today?

display_name: Health Interview (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): How stressful was day today
description: 7. How stressful was your day today?  Was it: (check one.)

display_name: Body mass index (BMI)
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :bmi_s1: at Visit 1, and :bmi_s2: at Visit 2

display_name: Diastolic blood pressure
description:
Average resting diastolic blood pressure of two measurements collected from the upper arm in a single clinic visit. When more than two measurements were collected, the average was calculated using the second and third measurements. In cases where either of the measurements was missing, the average was calculated discarding the missing value.

Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :diasbp:

display_name: Systolic blood pressure
description:
Average resting systolic blood pressure of two measurements collected from the upper arm in a single clinic visit. When more than two measurements were collected, the average was calculated using the second and third measurements. In cases where either of the measurements was missing, the average was calculated discarding the missing value.

Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :systbp:

display_name: Subject age
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :age_s1: at Visit 1 and :age_s2: at Visit 2

display_name: Indicates whether the subject's age (in years) used during date obfuscation is greater than 89 years
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :age_s1: at Visit 1 and :age_s2: at Visit 2

display_name: Subject ethnicity
description:
Original missing value is recoded as "not reported".

Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :ethnicity:

display_name: Subject race
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :race:

display_name: Subject sex
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :gender:

display_name: Currently smoking cigarettes
description:
Indicates whether subject currently smokes cigarettes.

Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :smokstat_s1: at Visit 1 and :smokstat_s2: at Visit 2

display_name: Ever smoked cigarettes
description:
Indicates whether subject ever regularly smoked cigarettes.

Harmonized by the NSRR team to align with TOPMed and BioDataCatalyst standards. Source: :smokstat_s1: at Visit 1 and :smokstat_s2: at Visit 2

display_name: Apnea-Hypopnea Index : (All apneas + hypopneas with >=30% nasal cannula [or alternative sensor] reduction and >= 3% oxygen desaturation or with arousal) / hour of sleep
description:
Harmonized by the NSRR team.

The definition for hypopneas is consistent with the following clinical guidelines: (1) American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) 2007 Manual (2012 update) (recommended). [Berry RB et al. 2012 (PubMed ID:23066376)] (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23066376), and (2) American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) 2015 (recommended) [Berry RB et al. The AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events: Rules, Terminology and Technical Specifications, Version 2.2. American Academy of Sleep Medicine, Darien, IL, 2015.]

Refer to the source for detailed definition for respiratory events: :ahi_a0h3a:

display_name: Apnea-Hypopnea Index : (All apneas + hypopneas with >= 3% oxygen desaturation) / hour of sleep
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Refer to the source for detailed definition for respiratory events: :ahi_a0h3:

display_name: Apnea-Hypopnea Index : (All apneas + hypopneas with >= 4% oxygen desaturation or with arousal) / hour of sleep
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Refer to the source for detailed definition for respiratory events: :ahi_a0h4a:

display_name: Apnea-Hypopnea Index : (All apneas + hypopneas with >=30% nasal cannula [or alternative sensor] reduction with >= 4% oxygen desaturation) / hour of sleep
description:
Harmonized by the NSRR team.

The definition of hypopnea events is consistent with the following clinical guidelines: (1) AASM 2012 update (alternative) [Berry RB et al. 2012 (PubMed ID:23066376)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23066376), and (2) AASM 2015 (acceptable) [Berry RB et al. The AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events: Rules, Terminology and Technical Specifications, Version 2.2. American Academy of Sleep Medicine, Darien, IL, 2015.].

Refer to the source for detailed definition for respiratory events: :ahi_a0h4:

display_name: Arousal Index: Number of arousals per hour of sleep from polysomnography
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :ai_all:

display_name: Study scored sleep/wake rather than with full sleep staging if there is not sufficient quality on EEG lead. Studies scored as sleep wake have all sleep stages scored using a default of Stage 2 and no arousals are scored.
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :staging5:

display_name: Percentage of total sleep duration (i.e., total sleep time, TST) in stage 1 from polysomnography
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :timest1p:

display_name: Percentage of total sleep duration (i.e., total sleep time, TST) in stage 2 from polysomnography
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :timest2p:

display_name: Percentage of total sleep duration (i.e., total sleep time, TST) in stage 3/4 from polysomnography
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :times34p:

display_name: Percentage of total sleep duration (i.e., total sleep time, TST) in REM from polysomnography
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :timeremp:

display_name: Total Sleep Duration: the interval between sleep onset and sleep offset while the participant is asleep from polysomnography
description:
Conventionally, this would be called total sleep time (TST) (i.e. total time spent in stage 1 or greater).

Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :slpprdp:

display_name: REM Sleep Latency: the interval between the first sleep epoch and REM sleep excluding wake
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :remlaiip:

display_name: Wake After Sleep Onset: the total duration being awake between sleep onset and lights-on/out-bed time from polysomnography
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :waso:

display_name: Sleep Efficiency: the ratio of total sleep duration (i.e., total sleep time) to in-bed period (i.e., time in bed) from polysomnography
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :slpeffp:

display_name: Sleep Latency: the interval between lights-out/in-bed time and sleep onset from polysomnography
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :slplatp:

display_name: Total In-bed Period: the interval between lights off/in-bed time and lights on/out-bed time from polysomnography
description:
Harmonized by the NSRR team. Conventionally, this would be called time in bed (TIB)

Source: :timebedp:

display_name: REM Sleep Latency: the interval between the first sleep epoch and REM sleep including wake
description: Harmonized by the NSRR team. Source: :remlaip:

Apnea-Hypopnea Index: (Apneas with no oxygen desaturation threshold used and with or without arousal+ hypopneas with > 30% flow reduction and >= 3% oxygen desaturation and with or without arousal) / hour of sleep from type II polysomnography
description: Calculated - Summary metric of sleep disordered breathing events.
calculation: 60 * (hrembp3 + hrop3 + hnrbp3 + hnrop3 + carbp + carop + canbp + canop + oarbp + oarop + oanbp + oanop) / slpprdp

display_name: Apnea-Hypopnea Index: (Apneas with no oxygen desaturation threshold used and with or without arousal+ hypopneas with > 30% flow reduction and >= 3% oxygen desaturation or with arousal) / hour of sleep from type II polysomnography
description:
Calculated - Summary metric of sleep disordered breathing events. The definition for hypopneas is consistent with the following clinical guidelines: (1) American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) 2007 Manual (2012 update) (recommended). [Berry RB et al. 2012 (PubMed ID:23066376)] (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23066376), and (2) American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) 2015 (recommended) [Berry RB et al. The AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events: Rules, Terminology and Technical Specifications, Version 2.2. American Academy of Sleep Medicine, Darien, IL, 2015.]

[Search for all AHI variables consistent with the same clinical guidelines within this dataset]( https://sleepdata.org/datasets/shhs/variables?search=aasm15_recommended)
calculation: 60 * (hremba3 + hroa3 + hnrba3 + hnroa3 + carbp + carop + canbp + canop + oarbp + oarop + oanbp + oanop) / slpprdp

display_name: Apnea-Hypopnea Index: (Apneas with no oxygen desaturation threshold used and with or without arousal+ hypopneas with > 30% flow reduction and >= 4% oxygen desaturation and with or without arousal) / hour of sleep from type II polysomnography
description:
Calculated - Summary metric of sleep disordered breathing events. The definition of hypopnea events is consistent with the following clinical guidelines: (1) AASM 2012 update (alternative) [Berry RB et al. 2012 (PubMed ID:23066376)] (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23066376), and (2) AASM 2015 (acceptable) [Berry RB et al. The AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events: Rules, Terminology and Technical Specifications, Version 2.2. American Academy of Sleep Medicine, Darien, IL, 2015.].

[Search for all AHI variables consistent with the same clinical guidelines within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/shhs/variables?search=aasm15_acceptable)
calculation: 60 * (hrembp4 + hrop4 + hnrbp4 + hnrop4 + carbp + carop + canbp + canop + oarbp + oarop + oanbp + oanop) / slpprdp

display_name: Apnea-Hypopnea Index: Apneas with no oxygen desaturation threshold used and with or without arousal+ hypopneas with > 30% flow reduction and with no oxygen desaturation used and with or without arousal / hour of sleep from type II polysomnography
description: Calculated - Summary metric of sleep disordered breathing events

description: Calculated - Summary metric of sleep disordered breathing events
calculation: 60 * ( hrop + hnrop + carop + canop + oarop + oanop ) / ( remepop + nremepop )

display_name: Average Normalized EEG Power
description:
In some PSGs the EEG is generally low in amplitude in all frequency ranges while in others it is high. The reasons for these differences could be technical (distance between active and reference electrode, electrode impedance), biological (e.g. age, skin or skull impedance) or some other reason [Younes et al. 2021 (PubMed ID: 34156473)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34156473/).

This index was recently found to be a risk factor for future development of dementia [(Stone et al. 2018)](https://doi.org/10.1093/sleep/zsy061.1012). In addition, it was found to be highly reproducible across 5 years of follow up. A high value also results in artifactually high spindle power and density and higher alpha intrusion.

[Search for all EEG variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/shhs/variables?search=eeg_shhs)

display_name: Average ORP Over Total Recording Time
description:
Average Odds Ratio Product (ORP) in all 30-s epochs during total recording time.

ORP is a continuous index of sleep depth and wake propensity. A value of 0 indicates very deep sleep, a value of 2.5 indicates full wakefulness.

[Search for all EEG variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/shhs/variables?search=eeg_shhs)

display_name: Change in ORP across the night
description:
Change in Odds Ratio Product (ORP) across the night, a greater increase in ORP from the beginning of to end of the night suggests more restorative sleep. [Younes et al. 2020 (PubMed ID: 32729619)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32729619/).

Source: :avg_orp_last120m_nrem: and :min_orp_firsthalf_nrem:.

display_name: Icc R/L Orp
description:
Intraclass correlation between right and left Odds Ratio Product (ORP) across all epochs in Total Recording Time (TRT). A high correlation indicates good agreement in sleep depth between right and left hemispheres. The reasons for a low correlation could be:
a) reduced range of ORP across TRT (e.g., little stage wake or deep sleep)
b) systematic difference between the two electrodes (e.g. noise in one electrode or unilateral brain pathology)
c) true dissociation between right and left sleep (Dolphin sleep).

:icc_ms_rows:, :icc_ms_col: and :icc_ms_error: distinguish between these three possibilities, respectively.

[Younes et al. 2021 (PubMed ID: 34156473)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34156473/)
[Dres et al. 2019 (PubMed ID: 30818966)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30818966/)
[Azarbarzin et al. 2021 (PubMed ID: 32441843)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32441843/)

display_name: Orp-9
description:
Rate of sleep recovery following arousals. A high value reflects slow recovery and suggests high central arousability (Hyperarousal state).

[Younes et al. 2021 (PubMed ID: 34156473)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34156473/)
[Younes and Hanley 2016 (PubMed ID: 26718786)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26718786/)

display_name: Distribution of epochs in 0.25-0.5% ORP decile
description:
Distribution of 30-s epochs, as a percent of total recording time in different Odds Ratio Product (ORP) deciles. [Younes et al. 2022 (PubMed ID: 35272350)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35272350/)

ORP is a continuous index of sleep depth and wake propensity. A value of 0 indicates very deep sleep; a value of 2.5 indicates full wakefulness. These values are used to construct the ORP histogram and ORP phenotype (:orp_type:).

Average oxygen saturation during total sleep duration from type II polysomnography
calculation: ( ( avsao2nh ) * ( timest1p + timest2p + times34p ) + ( avsao2rh ) * ( timeremp ) ) / 100

display_name: Average oxygen saturation during NREM sleep from type II polysomnography
description: The mean of all oxygen saturation (SaO2) values in epochs scored as stages other than rapid eye movement sleep (REM) (i.e., 1,2,3/4).

display_name: Average oxygen saturation during REM sleep from type II polysomnography
description: The mean of all oxygen saturation (SaO2) values in epochs scored as stage REM (Rapid eye movement sleep).

display_name: Minimum oxygen saturation during total sleep duration from type II polysomnography
description: Lowest oxygen saturation (SaO2)% during sleep
calculation: min(losao2r,losao2nr)

Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit One (SHHS1)): Overall signal quality
description: Overall study grade as assigned by scorer.  The overall quality grade is based on the quality and duration of EEG, respiratory and oximetry signals. Based on signal quality during recording time. Studies are given a study code varying from outstanding to fair. If interested in studies of the best quality, overall quality scores of Very Good, Excellent and Oustanding can be selected. This code reflects the total duration of useable (artifact free, scorable) signals across channels, weighing those signals most critical for accurate scoring of respiratory events and staging.

description: Sleep Heart Health Study Visit One (SHHS1)-Vary from 1 (poorest) to 4 (best) and reflect the proportion of time the signals were useable.

description: When the technical quality of the EEG does not allow distinction between sleep stages, but allows a differentiation between sleep and wake.  The time considered sleep will be marked as Stage 2.  No arousals will be scored for these studies.

description: Scorer observed alpha intrusion on sleep during study.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Apnea/Hypopnea scoring problems
description: Due to signal problems, scorer was unable to reliably distinguish between apnea and hypopnea events.  The distinction between apnea and hypopnea was determined to be unreliable.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Arousals Ignored
description: Due to problems with EEG signals, arousals were ignored in scoring.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Problems with arousals
description: Scorer noted that there was a problem scoring arousals.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Arousals unreliable
description: Due to signal problems, scorer was unable to reliably assess arousals.  The scoring of arousals was determined to be unreliable.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Signal Quality comments
description: Scorer comments on signal quality issues observed.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Periodic breathing (10 minutes)
description: Scorer observed periodic breathing for a period of at least 10 minutes during study.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Periodic large breaths
description: Scorer observed periodic large breaths during study.  When very large breaths (one or two) occur periodically (mostly on the inductance channels) between runs of fairly normal breaths for a duration of at least 10 minutes.

display_name: Was the light sensor calibrated appropriately?
description: Sleep Heart Health Study Visit 2 (SHHS2)- Lights are considered to have been calibrated appropriately if, at any time during the study, there is a clear transition (on recorded lights) from lights on to lights off.  Otherwise, lights are considered not appropriate (including a light channel showing: no change throughout the study, reversed calibration and/or constant fluctuation from on to off throughout the study.)  On studies with clear, but multiple, light transitions "lights off" will be marked at the first "off" transition that is maintained for at least 30 minutes.  Light calibration will be considered reliable, but sleep latency will be unreliable.  This method will be employed for all studies with the only exception being when onset of sleep occurs prior to the light change, in which "lights off" will be set at the onset of sleep.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Data Lost at beginning of study
description: Data was lost at the beginning of study due to unscorable signals.  Variable not used for Sleep Heart Health Study Visit 1 (SHHS1)

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Data Lost during study
description: Data was lost during the study.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Data Lost at end of study
description: Data was lost at end of study due to unscorable signals.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Long respiratory events verified
description: If a respiratory event greater than 150 seconds in duration was observed, scorer has verified that this value is real.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Other outlier
description: Scorer observed other outlying values.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Overall signal quality
description: Overall study grade as assigned by scorer.  These codes reflected the total duration of useable (artifact free, scorable) signals during sleep time across channels, weighing those signals most critical for accurate scoring of respiratory events and staging during sleep time.  The Quality Assessment Form for SHHS2 was modified so that the overall quality grade and the signal quality codes were based on signals during sleep time.  Since events were only scored during sleep time this provided a more accurate assessment of signal quality during the actual time or scoring.   This change would only have affected the quality grade of a small number of studies in SHHS1 where there was a significant amount of time awake with very good signals combined with very poor signals that occurred during sleep.   The overall and signal quality grades are comparable between SHHS1 and SHHS2.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Periodic breathing (5 min)
description: Scorer observed periodic breathing for a period of at least 5 minutes during study.

description: Due to signal problems, scorer was unable to reliably assess arousals in stage rapid eye movement sleep (REM).  The scoring of arousals in stage rapid eye movement sleep (REM) was determined to be unreliable.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): rapid eye movement sleep (REM)/non-rapid eye movement sleep (NREM) Scoring unreliable

description: Due to signal problems, scorer noted that there was a problem scoring respiratory events.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Sleep Wake Scoring
description: Study was scored sleep/wake rather than with full sleep staging.  This assessment is made by the scorer if there is not sufficient quality on EEG leads to do full R&K scoring.  (0=no (full scoring); 1=yes (sleep/wake only)) Studies scored as sleep wake have all sleep stages scored using a default of Stage 2 and no arousals are scored.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Stage1/Stage2 Scoring unreliable
description: Scorer noted that there was a problem differentiating stage 1 and stage 2 sleep.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Stage2/Stage3-4 Scoring unreliable
description: Scorer noted that there was a problem differentiating stage 2 and stage 3/4 sleep.

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Unusual Staging
description: Scorer observed unusual sleep staging.  This is noted when there is no sleep in any particular stage (eg. no rapid eye movement sleep (REM)).

display_name: Polysomnography (PSG) Quality Assessment (Sleep Heart Health Study Visit Two (SHHS2)): Wake/Sleep Scoring unreliable
description: Scorer noted that there was a problem differentiating stage wake from stage sleep.

Sleep Efficiency: the ratio of sleep duration (i.e., total sleep time) to in-bed period (i.e., time in bed) from type II polysomnography
description: Sleep duration is the interval between sleep onset time and lights on/out-bed time while asleep (i.e. total sleep time, TST), while in-bed period is the interval between lights off/in-bed time and lights on/out-bed time (i.e. time in bed, TIB).Percentage of time in bed that was spent sleeping, or the ratio of total sleep time to total time in bed, expressed as a percentage.

display_name: Sleep Latency: the interval between lights-out/in-bed time and sleep onset time from type II polysomnography
Total Sleep Duration: the interval between sleep onset and sleep offset while the participant is asleep from type II polysomnography
description: Conventionally this variable would be called total sleep time (TST)(i.e. total time spent in stage 1 or greater).

display_name: Total number of shift (sleep stages shift) from sleep to awake from type II polysomnography
Total number of shift (sleep stages shift) from stage 2 to stage 1 sleep from type II polysomnography
Total number of shift (sleep stages shift) from stage 3/4 to stage 1/2 sleep from type II polysomnography
Clock time when the participant is in bed or lights are out from type II polysomnography
description:
Conventionally, this variable would be called the start of time in bed (TIB).

In Visit 1 this variable represents the number of epochs from recording start.

display_name: Sleep onset time from type II polysomnography
description:
Conventionally this variable would be called the start of total sleep time (TST) (i.e. total time spent in stage 1 or greater).

In Visit 1 this variable represents the number of epochs from recording start.

display_name: Percentage of total sleep duration in supine position from type II polysomnography
calculation: 100 * ( remepbp + nremepbp ) / slpprdp

display_name: Total In-bed Period: the interval between lights out/in-bed time and lights off/out-bed time from type II polysomnography
description: Calculated. Conventionally this variable would be called time in bed (TIB).

display_name: Total duration of REM sleep from type II polysomnography
description: Total time scored as rapid eye movement sleep (REM) rounded to nearest minute
calculation: minremp

display_name: Percentage of total sleep duration in REM from type II polysomnography
description: The ratio of time in rapid eye movement sleep (REM) to total sleep time, expressed as a percentage.
calculation: tmremp

display_name: Percentage of total sleep duration in stage 3 and 4 from type II polysomnography
calculation: tmstg34p

display_name: Total duration of stage 1 sleep from type II polysomnography
description: Total time scored as stage 1 rounded to nearest minute
calculation: minstg1p

display_name: Percentage of total sleep duration in stage 1 from type II polysomnography
calculation: tmstg1p

display_name: Total duration of stage 2 sleep from type II polysomnography
description: Total time scored as stage 2 rounded to nearest minute
calculation: minstg2p

display_name: Percentage of total sleep duration in stage 2 from type II polysomnography
calculation: tmstg2p

display_name: Total duration of stage 3 and 4 sleep from type II polysomnography
description: Total time scored as stage 3/4 rounded to nearest minute
calculation: mnstg34p

display_name: Wake after Sleep Onset: the total duration between sleep onset and sleep offset time while being awake from type II polysomnography
description: Total amount of time spent awake after going to sleep
calculation: timebedp - slpprdp - slplatp

display_name: Chance of dozing at dinner table
description: Additional item added to the Epworth Sleepiness Scale

display_name: Epworth Sleepiness Scale: Total score
description:
Calculated - Total score based on an 8-item questionnaires ranking likelihood of dozing off [Johns MW 1991 (PubMed ID: 1798888)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1798888). Scale 0-3 for individual items; 0 to 24 for overall score.

[Search for all ESS variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/abc/variables?search=epworth)
calculation: sum(sitread-1,watchtv-1,sitpublic-1,ridecar-1,resting-1,sittalk-1,sitafterlunch-1,stoppedcar-1)

display_name: Epworth Sleepiness Scale: Chance of dozing while lying down in the afternoon when circumstances permit
